title: Cut Copy
comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead.) #IABot (v2.0.9.2
text:
{{short description|Australian synth-pop band}}
{{Use Australian English|date=June 2011}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2020}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name            = Cut Copy
| image           = Cut Copy (45668059095).jpg
| alt             =
| caption         = Cut Copy performing at [[Falls Festival]] in [[Byron Bay]], 2018
| image_size      = 250
| landscape       = yes
| origin          = [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia
| genre           = {{hlist|[[Synth-pop]]|[[indietronica]]|[[dance-punk]]|[[New wave music|new wave]]}}
| years_active    = 2001–present
| label           = {{hlist|[[Modular Recordings|Modular]]|[[Island Records|Island]]}}
| associated_acts =
| website         = {{URL|cutcopy.net/}}
| current_members = * Dan Whitford
* Tim Hoey
* Mitchell Scott
* Ben Browning
| past_members    = * [[Bennett Foddy]]
}}
'''Cut Copy''' (sometimes stylised as '''Cut/Copy''') are an Australian [[synth-pop]] band formed in 2001 by Dan Whitford (vocals, keyboards and guitar). Originally a home-recording project, the band now includes Tim Hoey (guitars), Ben Browning (bass guitar), and Mitchell Scott (drums).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://teezfm.com/2011/09/16/cut-copy/ |title=Interview Cut Copy ‹ TEEZ'FM |date=16 September 2011 |website=teezfm.com |access-date=10 December 2013}}</ref>

The band achieved breakthrough success in 2008 with their second album, ''[[In Ghost Colours]]'', which included well-known singles "[[Lights & Music]]" and "[[Hearts on Fire (Cut Copy song)|Hearts on Fire]]".

==History==

===Formation===
Cut Copy was established in 2001 in [[Melbourne]], Australia as the solo project of Dan Whitford, a DJ and graphic designer. Whitford was educated at [[Scotch College, Melbourne|Scotch College]] and studied graphic design at [[Monash University Faculty of Art Design & Architecture|Monash University]]. During his studies he became interested in dance music and began DJing while hosting a radio show. Around this time he bought a sampler and keyboards to experiment with. Musically he was "inspired by indie low-fi stuff as much as dance".<ref name="Sydney Morning Herald 2011">{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/cut-copy-move-on-from-the-modular-sound-20110203-1aeqz.html |title=Cut Copy move on from the "Modular sound" |author=Andrew Murfett |date=3 February 2011 |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |publisher=smh.com.au |access-date=26 November 2013}}</ref> Upon graduating Whitford co-founded the design agency Alter,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alter.com.au |title=Alter – Design Studio Melbourne. |publisher=alter.com.au |access-date=26 November 2013}}</ref> who continue to produce all of the graphical material for the band.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.australianedge.net/alter/ |title=Alter |date=26 November 2008 |publisher=australianedge.net |access-date=26 November 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220193743/http://www.australianedge.net/alter/ |archive-date=20 December 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

According to Whitford, the band's name was a random choice: "I was in the edit menu [of my computer] and I moved down in the document to the few words that didn't make sense together, and at that particular day and time the words 'cut' and 'copy' really stood out to me. At the time it felt like a fairly abstract choice but now it feels very tied in with what we do".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.spin.com/2011/01/why-theyre-called-cut-copy/ |title=Why They're Called... Cut Copy |date=4 January 2011 |author=David Marchese |work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] |publisher=spin.com |access-date=18 November 2013}}</ref> The name is often displayed as one word with a forward slash in between: Cut/Copy.

Whitford began producing music at his home-studio and submitted a demo-tape to [[Modular Recordings]], who subsequently signed him sometime in the first half of 2001. He enlisted the help of veteran guitarist [[Harry Howard (musician)|Harry Howard]] to record the debut single "1981", which was released on vinyl only.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://popshifter.com/2012-06-19/harry-howard-the-near-death-experience-near-death-experience/ |title=Harry Howard & the Near Death Experience, Near Death Experience |date=19 June 2012 |author=Julie Finley |publisher=popshifter.com |access-date=26 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="Resident Advisor 2002">{{cite web |url=http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature.aspx?80 |title=RA: Cut Copy Interview |date=24 February 2002 |author=Dylan Behan |publisher=residentadvisor.net |access-date=30 November 2013 |archive-date=3 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203064655/http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature.aspx?80 |url-status=dead }}</ref> With Howard filling in on guitar, Whitford asked his childhood friend [[Bennett Foddy]] to join on bass with the view to release an EP.<ref name="Bennett">{{cite web |url=http://killscreendaily.com/articles/profile-bennett-foddy/ |title=Profile: Bennett Foddy |date=25 May 2011 |author=Jonathan Beilin |publisher=killscreendaily.com |access-date=26 November 2013}}</ref> The band was assisted by Robbie Chater of [[The Avalanches]] who produced the seven largely instrumental tracks that were leaning heavily on samples.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/features/27264/Cut-Copy/ |title=Cut Copy |date=8 February 2011 |publisher=fasterlouder.com.au |access-date=27 November 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203054138/http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/features/27264/Cut-Copy |archive-date=3 December 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> ''[[I Thought of Numbers]]'' was released in September 2001 and spurred a number of remixes on vinyl. The following year saw Whitford remould the band with a view to take to the stage. Their live debut was at the 2003 [[Livid (festival)|Livid]] festival where they performed in front of 5,000 people.<ref name="Bennett"/>

In 2003, Howard was replaced by Tim Hoey, a student at the [[Faculty of Fine Arts and Music, University of Melbourne|Victoria College of Art]] after he and Whitford began exchanging demo tapes.<ref name="Sydney Morning Herald 2011"/> Drummer Mitchell Scott joined shortly after, explaining that "we were just in the same circle of friends, and Tim was sort of roped in because he could play guitar and Dan's sampler had actually broken down, which kind of brought on the need to find a new way of thinking about a live show".<ref name="Mitchel Scott interview 2013">{{cite web |url=http://www.futuremusicgroup.com.au/tag/mitchell-scott/ |title=Interview: Cut Copy |date=25 October 2013 |publisher=futuremusicgroup.com.au |access-date=28 November 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131119064113/http://www.futuremusicgroup.com.au/tag/mitchell-scott/ |archive-date=19 November 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Prior to Hoey and Scott joining, a Cut Copy performance was essentially Whitford together with Joel McKenzie doing a DJ set that included sampling their own material. Throughout their career, the band has continued to do DJ sets and remixes for others.<ref name="Resident Advisor 2002" /><ref name="DJ agency listing">{{cite web |url=http://www.windishagency.com/artists/cut_copy_dj_set |title=The Windish Agency: Cut Copy DJs |publisher=windishagency.com |access-date=30 November 2013 |archive-date=3 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203052213/http://www.windishagency.com/artists/cut_copy_dj_set |url-status=dead }}</ref>

===2003–2006: ''Bright Like Neon Love''===
Whitford began working on the band's debut album in early 2003 and had written half a dozen songs when during a DJ gig, one of their samplers broke down. Together with Hoey, Scott and Foddy he began reinterpreting the material. Later in the year, Whitford gathered all the recordings and travelled to Paris to mix the album with [[Cassius (band)|Phillippe Zdar]] and his team, and found that he had "two different versions of the recordings, so I started taking parts from both of those, and putting them together".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tlchicken.com/view_story.php?ARTid=2347 |title=CUT COPY'S DAN WHITFORD |date=May 2004 |publisher=tlchicken.com |access-date=28 November 2013}}</ref> In April 2004, Cut Copy released their debut LP ''[[Bright Like Neon Love]]'' to moderate success, supported by the singles "Future" and "Saturdays". The four-piece began rehearsing for a tour and began to play 'a garage band version' of the material.<ref name="Sydney Morning Herald 2011" /> At this stage Foddy left the group to study for his PhD, and the band continued as a three-piece.<ref name=Bennett />

In 2005, the trio toured internationally for the first time, as support to international acts such as [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]], [[The Presets]], [[Junior Senior]], [[Bloc Party]] and [[Mylo]] while also playing a number of European festivals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.songkick.com/artists/20422-cut-copy/gigography?page=10 |title=Cut Copy Gigography, Tour History |publisher=[[Songkick]] |work=songkick.com |access-date=27 November 2013}}</ref> By playing a large number of shows their fan-base grew and three members became more proficient in their instruments. In contrast to previous occasions, Whitford began songwriting with the others in the band.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/quite-a-journey-for-cut-copy-founder-dan-whitford/story-e6frf96f-1111115800249 |title=Quite a journey for Cut Copy founder Dan Whitford |date=16 March 2008 |publisher=heraldsun.com.au |work=[[Herald Sun]] |access-date=6 December 2013}}</ref> In the first half of 2006, Whitford was asked to produce a mix for the [[Fabric (club)|Fabric]] label, which included a number of Cut Copy mixes. It was released in August 2006 as ''[[FabricLive.29]]'' and described as "collection of indie, hip-hop, electroclash and straight up rock".<ref name="Something Glorious">{{cite web |url=http://somethingglorious.typepad.com/somethingglorious/2006/09/interview_cut_c.html |title=Interview: Dan Whitford of Cut Copy for FabricLive |date=21 September 2006 |publisher=somethingglorious.typepad.com |access-date=6 December 2013}}</ref> He did the same for the American clothing company Triple 5 Soul in the same year, which Modular later released as a podcast.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.modularpeople.com/modcast/33-old-gold-a-night-out-with-cut-copy-2006/2200.html |title=Modcast #33: Old Gold - A Night Out With Cut Copy (2006) |publisher=modularpeople.com |access-date=10 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131218085957/http://www.modularpeople.com/modcast/33-old-gold-a-night-out-with-cut-copy-2006/2200.html |archive-date=18 December 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

===2007–2009: ''In Ghost Colours''===
[[File:Cut-copy1.jpg|thumb|Cut Copy performing at [[Point Éphémère]] in [[Paris]], 2008]]
For much of 2006, Whitford had been working on the second album using the three-piece template that had been touring the world. Towards the end of September, he had much of the album complete in demo form.<ref name="Something Glorious" /> These recordings were sent to [[Tim Goldsworthy]] who agreed to produce the new record. In early 2007 the band travelled to New York where the new album was completed in a six-week period.<ref name="tinymixtapes">{{cite web |url=http://www.tinymixtapes.com/features/cut-copy |title=Cut Copy: Interview |date=June 2008 |work=[[Tiny Mix Tapes]] |publisher=tinymixtapes.com |access-date=2 January 2014}}</ref> Whitford commented on Goldsworthy's contribution that "he was almost like an extra member of the band and gave us feedback on things that were working and things that he thought we could change. On top of that he has an incredible wealth of experience with what he's done with other records and brought some of those recording techniques to our music".<ref name="about.com">{{cite web |url=http://dancemusic.about.com/od/artistshomepages/a/CutCopyIntervie.htm |title=Cut Copy Interview - Interview with Cut Copy |date=26 August 2008 |author=Ron Slomowicz |work=[[About.com]] |publisher=dancemusic.about.com |access-date=2 January 2014}}</ref> After some mixing in Los Angeles, the album was finalised at the band's homebase in Melbourne.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jasontreuen.wordpress.com/2008/05/04/rolling-stone-cut-copy-directors-cut/ |title=Rolling Stone: Cut Copy (director's cut) |date=4 May 2008 |author=Jason Treuen |publisher=jasontreuen.wordpress.com |access-date=2 January 2014}}</ref>

In May 2007, the band decided to play a small Australian tour while Modular Recordings released the single "[[Hearts on Fire (Cut Copy song)|Hearts on Fire]]" digitally and on vinyl.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cut-copy.blogspot.co.uk/2007/05/hearts-on-fire-tour-2007.html |title=cut/copy: HEARTS ON FIRE tour 2007! |date=3 May 2007 |publisher=cut-copy.blogspot.co.uk |access-date=8 May 2014}}</ref> In September, the band had announced the completion of their second album, ''[[In Ghost Colours]]'', but its Australian release was delayed until 22 March 2008 to co-ordinate with its international release. The rest of the year was spent doing remixes and playing a number of local festivals. In December 2007, the group toured Australia with [[Daft Punk]] on the Nevereverland tour, and the Sydney leg of which attracted a crowd of almost 50,000 people. The promo-only single "So Haunted" was made available for airplay while Whitford was putting together another compilation of mixes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cut-copy.blogspot.co.uk/2007/05/hearts-on-fire-tour-2007.html |title=cut/copy: Rumours |date=26 November 2007 |publisher=cut-copy.blogspot.co.uk |access-date=8 May 2014}}</ref>

As a prelude to their second album, the band released the ''So Cosmic'' mix in February 2008, showing the disco/new wave inspiration behind ''In Ghost Colours''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/Cut-Copy-So-Cosmic/release/1239333 |title=Cut Copy - So Cosmic (CD) at Discogs |publisher=[[Discogs]] |work=discogs.com |access-date=8 May 2014}}</ref> The album debuted on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]] at number one<ref name="AUS">{{cite web | url = http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Cut+Copy | title = Discography Cut Copy | publisher = Hung Medien | work = Australian Charts Portal | access-date = 7 August 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://undercover.com.au/News-Story.aspx?id=4417 |title = Number One For Cut Copy Is A Bittersweet Victory |access-date = 11 May 2008 |author = Paul Cashmere |date = 1 April 2008 |publisher = Undercover.com.au |url-status = dead |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080722171207/http://undercover.com.au/News-Story.aspx?id=4417 |archive-date = 22 July 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> and was also a minor chart success in the UK and the US. Cut Copy's next single, "[[Lights & Music]]" was used in video game ''[[FIFA 09]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.operationsports.com/press/73/ea-sports-fifa-09-soundtrack-score-on-international-music-goals/|title=EA Sports FIFA 09 Soundtrack Score on International Music Goals|author=Steve Noah|date=14 August 2008|publisher=operationsports.com|access-date=20 December 2014}}</ref> It reached the top 10 in the Australian dance chart and became their most popular song. "Far Away", album's third and final single, was played on ''[[Nip/Tuck]]'', a United States TV series, on one of its final episodes, in a club scene.

===2010–2012: ''Zonoscope''===
[[File:Cut Copy 8.jpg|thumb|Cut Copy performing in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn]], August 2010]]
In July 2010, radio station [[Triple J]] broadcast the teaser track "Where I'm Going" ahead of Cut Copy's third album, ''[[Zonoscope]]'', which drew inspirations from the early 1980s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/features/interviews/7934-cut-copy/|title=Interviews: Cut Copy|author=Tom Breihan|date=21 February 2011|publisher=pitchfork.com|work=[[Pitchfork Media]]|access-date=15 March 2014}}</ref> It was largely recorded in a Melbourne warehouse with only the band and an engineer working on it.<ref name="Mitchel Scott interview 2013" /> The band confirmed that they had officially become a four-piece with the addition of bass guitarist Ben Browning.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-news/artists/2010/07/15/exclusive-cut-copy-to-premiere-where-im-going-this-friday/|title= Cut Copy to premiere Where I'm Going this Friday|work=[[The Music Network]]|author=Jason Treuen|access-date=15 July 2010}}</ref> "Where I'm Going" became the theme song of [[BlackBerry Limited|RIM]]'s [[BlackBerry PlayBook]]'s sneak-preview video, which was released in September 2010.

The band premiered the new single "[[Take Me Over (Cut Copy song)|Take Me Over]]" in November 2010 on Triple J's breakfast show with Tom & Alex. In an interview with ''[[The Music Network]]'', guitarist Tim Hoey described it as "certainly one of the more pop moments on the album."<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-news/artists/2010/11/19/cut-copy-to-premiere-new-single-take-me-over-this-tuesday/|title= Cut Copy discuss new single ahead of Tuesday premiere|work=[[The Music Network]]|access-date=19 November 2010}}</ref> ''Zonoscope'' peaked at number three in Australia in February 2011<ref name="AUS"/> and was a considerable success internationally. In March 2011, the group performed on the Saturday of the [[Ultra Music Festival]] in Miami, US.<ref>{{cite news |title=Set Times For Ultra Music Festival 2011 |url=http://blogs.miaminewtimes.com/crossfade/2011/03/set_times_for_ultra_music_fest.php |access-date=5 September 2012 |newspaper=[[Miami New Times]] |date=24 March 2011 |author=Jose D. Duran}}</ref> In June, they played at the Indie Fest in [[Puerto Rico]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Coors Light Indie Fest 2011|url=http://www.mydestination.com/puertorico/events/73118721/coors-light-indie-fest-2011-4-june-2011|work=My Destination|publisher=mydestination.com|access-date=5 September 2012|year=2011}}</ref> and two dates in [[Tel Aviv]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/cutcopy/status/65840795802009600|title=cut copy on Twitter|date=4 May 2011|publisher=[[Twitter]]|work=twitter.com|access-date=20 December 2014}}</ref> In July, the band performed to an audience of 25,000 people at the Camp Bisco festival in [[Mariaville Lake, New York]], and in September played the [[Virgin Festival|Virgin Mobile FreeFest]] in [[Columbia, Maryland]], US.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://virginmobilefestival.com/ |title=Virgin Mobile Freefest 2013 - Home |publisher=Virginmobilefestival.com |date=2013-09-21 |access-date=2014-07-23 |archive-date=1 December 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101201114347/http://virginmobilefestival.com/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> ''Zonoscope'' was supported by further singles "Need You Now" and "Blink and You'll Miss a Revolution" in 2011.

In March 2012, Cut Copy bassist Ben Browning released his debut solo EP ''Lover Motion''. It was preceded by the single "I Can't Stay".

===2013–2015: ''Free Your Mind''===
[[File:Cut Copy - Festival Primavera Fauna 2013.jpg|thumb|Cut Copy performing at the Fauna Primavera festival in Chile, 2013]]
In early September 2013, the full version of the title track to their fourth album ''[[Free Your Mind (Cut Copy album)|Free Your Mind]]'' debuted at six specific locations worldwide. Fans were informed that they could visit selected billboards in Mexico, Chile, Australia, two locations in the US (Detroit, and California) and one in the UK at Blaneau Gwent in South Wales. When fans were standing near the billboard, they could open an app which would allow them to stream the track through their smartphones.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cut Copy announce new album | url=http://www.nme.com/news/cut-copy/72576 | access-date=11 October 2013 | magazine=[[NME]] | date=10 September 2013}}</ref> The track quickly appeared on Triple J's hitlist getting regular airplay. The music video for "Free Your Mind", directed by Christopher Hill and released in October 2013, stars Swedish actor [[Alexander Skarsgård]] as a cult leader.<ref name="Mitchel Scott interview 2013" />

The album ''Free Your Mind'' was released on 1 November 2013, reaching the top 20 in Australia, but meeting with minor success in the UK and US charts. After rehearsals in Nashville, Cut Copy embarked on a world tour of North and South America through to Europe and Russia.<ref name="Mitchel Scott interview 2013" /> The music video for "We Are Explorers" premiered in February 2014, followed by the release of the vinyl single "In These Arms of Love" for [[Record Store Day]]. The latter was later included in the deluxe re-release of ''Free Your Mind''. In November, the band released a well-received mix album ''Oceans Apart''.

The band spent most of the 2015 working on the follow-up to ''Free Your Mind''. Another mix album, ''Forest Through the Trees'', was released in June and was followed by a DJ tour.

===2016–2019: ''Haiku from Zero''===
In September 2016, the band released ''January Tape'', a 44-minute [[Ambient music|ambient]] instrumental piece available as a limited cassette run of 400 copies.<ref>{{cite web|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/68676-cut-copy-release-44-minute-ambient-instrumental-january-tape/|title=Cut Copy Release 44-Minute Ambient Instrumental January Tape|date=30 September 2016|author=Kevin Lozano|access-date=30 December 2016}}</ref> According to Dan Whitford, the new album was about three-quarters complete as of October 2016.<ref>{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Fact (UK magazine)|Fact]]|url=http://www.factmag.com/2016/10/30/cut-copy-interview-the-january-tape/|title=Cut Copy's Dan Whitford on the new age influence behind January Tape and what to expect from their next album|date=30 October 2016|author=Claire Lobenfeld|access-date=30 December 2016}}</ref>

In July 2017, "Airborne" was released as the lead single from the new album. Next month, the band announced that the record would be called ''[[Haiku from Zero]]'' and simultaneously released the second single, "Standing in the Middle of the Field".<ref>{{cite web|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/cut-copy-announce-new-album-haiku-from-zero-share-new-song-listen/|title=Cut Copy Announce New Album Haiku From Zero, Share New Song: Listen|date=10 August 2017|author=Braudie Blais-Billie|access-date=10 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|magazine=[[PopMatters]]|url=https://www.popmatters.com/cut-copy-haiku-from-zero-2503795122.html|title=Cut Copy: Haiku from Zero|date=26 October 2017|author=Mike Schiller|access-date=21 November 2017}}</ref> The album was released on 22 September 2017 to mostly positive reviews. Despite this, it turned out Cut Copy's least commercially successful album since their debut ''[[Bright Like Neon Love]]'', peaking outside the top 50 in Australia and failing to enter general charts elsewhere. The band embarked on a tour to promote the new album, performing in North America, Australia, New Zealand, South America and Japan from 2017 to 2018. In November 2018, they released a new single, "Ocean Blue", which was recorded during ''Haiku from Zero'' sessions.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[Indie88]]|url=https://indie88.com/stream-cut-copy-release-new-single-ocean-blue/|title=STREAM: CUT COPY RELEASE NEW SINGLE 'OCEAN BLUE'|date=2 November 2018}}</ref> In 2019, Cut Copy played a series of concerts in Europe.

===2020–present: ''Freeze, Melt''===
On 8 May 2020, Cut Copy released a track, "Love Is All We Share", that was written about a year earlier.<ref>{{cite web|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/cut-copy-return-with-new-song-love-is-all-we-share-watch-the-video/|title=Cut Copy Return With New Song "Love Is All We Share": Watch the Video|date=8 May 2020|author=Noah Yoo|access-date=8 May 2020}}</ref> On 26 June 2020, the band announced their sixth full-length album, ''[[Freeze, Melt]]'', which was released on 21 August. The same day they released the lead song to the album, called "Cold Water".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Yoo|first=Noah|title=Cut Copy Announce New Album Freeze, Melt, Share New Song|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/cut-copy-announce-new-album-freeze-melt-share-new-song-listen/|access-date=2020-06-29|website=Pitchfork}}</ref>

==Band members==
'''Current members'''
* Dan Whitford – vocals, keyboard, guitar (2001–present)
* Tim Hoey – guitar, sampler (2003–present)
* Mitchell Scott – drums (2003–present)
* Ben Browning – bass guitar (2010–present)

'''Former members'''
* [[Bennett Foddy]] – bass, synth (2001–04)

==Discography==
{{Main|Cut Copy discography}}

* ''[[Bright Like Neon Love]]'' (2004)
* ''[[In Ghost Colours]]'' (2008)
* ''[[Zonoscope]]'' (2011)
* ''[[Free Your Mind (Cut Copy album)|Free Your Mind]]'' (2013)
* ''[[Haiku from Zero]]'' (2017)
* ''[[Freeze, Melt]]'' (2020)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/cut-copy-announce-new-album-freeze-melt-share-new-song-listen/ |title=Cut Copy announce new album 'Freeze, Melt', share new song: Listen |work=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |date=26 June 2020 |access-date=28 June 2020 |author=Yoo, Noah}}</ref>
